description:

The persistent Spotify music player at the bottom of the page cannot switch between songs. Pressing next/previous does nothing, even when on the Music page viewing Liked songs.

- Fix: Removed `hasContext` requirement from skip conditions - only `isActive` is needed

title: Music Audit: Fix device selector not loading on startup
description:
## Bug: Device Selector Not Loading on Startup

### Root Cause Analysis
The device refresh logic in `useSpotifyPlayer.ts` has a timing issue:

**Lines 522-530:**
```typescript
useEffect(() => {
  if (isAuthenticated && isPremium && !isReady) {
    // Fetch initial device list before SDK is ready
    refreshDevices()
  }
}, [isAuthenticated, isPremium, isReady, refreshDevices])
```

**The Problem:**
- This effect only runs when `!isReady` (SDK not ready yet)
- Once SDK becomes ready (`isReady = true`), this effect doesn't re-run
- The SDK ready handler (lines 252-292) has retry logic but may miss devices

**Race Condition:**
1. User authenticates → isAuthenticated=true
2. Effect runs → refreshDevices() → devices loaded
3. SDK initializes → isReady=true → effect doesn't re-run
4. SDK ready handler retries but devices array may be stale

### Additional Issue
The ready event handler (line 252) fetches devices but only updates if our device is found:
```typescript
if (ourDevice) {
  setDevices(deviceList)  // Only updates if our device exists
  // ...
}
```

If other devices exist but ours isn't registered yet, devices won't update.

### Fix Location
`hooks/useSpotifyPlayer.ts` lines 522-530 and 252-292

### Solution
1. Change useEffect to also run when `isReady` becomes true
2. In ready handler, always setDevices even if our device isn't found yet
3. Add periodic refresh when devices array is empty

### Test Steps
1. Clear all localStorage
2. Login to Spotify
3. Verify devices appear immediately without manual refresh
close_reason: Fixed in commits 944f992 and 2cfa67a

# Prompts Playground - Quad-Split Browser Viewer

## Overview

A 2x2 grid of browser panels for watching 4 agents build the same component simultaneously. Each agent works in an isolated project directory with its own dev server. You send them all the same prompt and watch the hot-reloading results side by side.

**Note:** Agent chat/terminals are visible in TabzChrome sidebar - this component is purely the visual comparison view.

## Use Case

1. Spawn 4 agents (via TabzChrome sidebar terminals)
2. Each runs in isolated directory with own dev server (ports 3001-3004)
3. Send same prompt to all: "Build a login form"
4. Watch all 4 build it differently in real-time via quad-split view
5. Compare approaches, pick the best implementation
6. **Save the winning component** with prompt + agent metadata for re-use

## Proposed UI

```

│ Prompts Playground                    [⚙️ Config]│
├───────────────────────┬─────────────────────────┤
│ Agent 1: opus+coder   │ Agent 2: sonnet+review  │

│ │ localhost:3001  │   │ │ localhost:3002  │     │
│ │                 │   │ │                 │     │
│ │  [Live Preview] │   │ │  [Live Preview] │     │
│ │                 │   │ │                 │     │
│ │   [💾 Save]     │   │ │   [💾 Save]     │     │

├───────────────────────┼─────────────────────────┤
│ Agent 3: codex/o3     │ Agent 4: haiku+fast     │

│ │                 │   │ │                 │     │

│ │   [💾 Save]     │   │ │   [💾 Save]     │     │
│ └─────────────────┘   │ └─────────────────┘     │
└───────────────────────┴─────────────────────────┘
│ [Refresh All] [Screenshot All]    [📚 Library]  │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
```

## Features

### Core Viewer
- **2x2 resizable grid** of iframe panels
- **Per-panel URL** (localhost:3001, 3002, 3003, 3004 or custom)
- **Per-panel label** (agent name/config for reference)
- **Auto-refresh** when dev servers hot reload
- **Responsive** - stack to 2x1 or 1x1 on mobile

### Panel Controls
- URL input (editable)
- Label/name input
- Refresh button
- Open in new tab
- Fullscreen single panel
- **Save component** button

### Component Library (New)
Save winning components for re-use with full metadata:

```
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│ 📚 Saved Components                    [Search] │
├─────────────────────────────────────────────────┤
│ ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │
│ │ Login Form v2                    2026-01-13 │ │
│ │ ─────────────────────────────────────────── │ │
│ │ Agent: opus + coder agent                   │ │

│ │         and forgot password link"          │ │
│ │ Files: components/LoginForm.tsx            │ │
│ │        components/LoginForm.css            │ │
│ │ ─────────────────────────────────────────── │ │
│ │ [Preview] [Copy Files] [Re-run Prompt]     │ │
│ └─────────────────────────────────────────────┘ │
│ ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │
│ │ Dashboard Card                   2026-01-12 │ │
│ │ ...                                         │ │
│ └─────────────────────────────────────────────┘ │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────┘
```

**Saved metadata per component:**
- Component name (user-provided)
- Timestamp
- Agent config (model, system prompt, flags)
- Prompt used to create it
- Source files (paths or inline code)
- Screenshot thumbnail
- Tags for organization

**Library actions:**
- **Preview** - View saved screenshot/code
- **Copy Files** - Copy component files to clipboard or target directory
- **Re-run Prompt** - Send same prompt to new agent session
- **Edit metadata** - Update name, tags, notes
- **Delete** - Remove from library

### Comparison Tools
- **Refresh all** - reload all 4 panels
- **Screenshot all** - capture current state of all 4
- **Save comparison** - save URLs + labels to localStorage
- **Load comparison** - restore saved configurations

## Technical Implementation

### File Structure
```
app/sections/prompts-playground.tsx     # Main section
components/prompts/
  QuadSplitViewer.tsx                   # 2x2 resizable grid
  BrowserPanel.tsx                      # Single iframe panel
  PanelControls.tsx                     # URL, label, refresh, save
  ComparisonToolbar.tsx                 # Bulk actions
  ComponentLibrary.tsx                  # Saved components view
  SaveComponentDialog.tsx               # Save form with metadata
  ComponentCard.tsx                     # Library item display
lib/prompts-playground.ts               # Types, localStorage helpers
```

### Types
```typescript
interface PanelConfig {
  url: string;          // e.g., "http://localhost:3001"
  label: string;        // e.g., "opus+coder"
  key: number;          // for forcing iframe refresh
  prompt?: string;      // current prompt being tested
  agentConfig?: AgentConfig;
}

interface AgentConfig {
  cli: 'claude' | 'codex';
  model: string;
  systemPrompt?: string;
  agent?: string;       // agent name from gallery
  flags?: Record<string, unknown>;
}

interface SavedComponent {
  id: string;
  name: string;
  createdAt: Date;
  prompt: string;
  agentConfig: AgentConfig;
  files: ComponentFile[];
  screenshot?: string;  // base64 or URL
  tags: string[];
  notes?: string;
}

interface ComponentFile {
  path: string;
  content: string;
  language: string;
}

interface PlaygroundState {
  panels: [PanelConfig, PanelConfig, PanelConfig, PanelConfig];
  currentPrompt: string;  // shared prompt input
  libraryOpen: boolean;
  savedComponents: SavedComponent[];
}
```

### Save Flow
1. User clicks "Save" on winning panel
2. Dialog opens with:
   - Component name input
   - Pre-filled prompt (from shared input)
   - Pre-filled agent config (from panel label/settings)
   - File picker (select which files to save)
   - Tags input
   - Notes textarea
3. Screenshot captured automatically
4. Saved to localStorage (or future: Supabase)

## Acceptance Criteria

### Viewer
- [ ] 2x2 resizable panel grid with iframes
- [ ] Each panel has editable URL and label
- [ ] Per-panel refresh button works
- [ ] Refresh all button reloads all 4 iframes
- [ ] Panel configs persist to localStorage
- [ ] Mobile responsive (stacks panels)

### Component Library
- [ ] Save button on each panel opens save dialog
- [ ] Can enter component name, prompt, agent config
- [ ] Can select files to include (path + content)
- [ ] Screenshot captured on save
- [ ] Saved components listed in library view
- [ ] Can search/filter saved components
- [ ] Can preview saved component (screenshot + code)
- [ ] Can copy files to clipboard
- [ ] Can re-run prompt with same config
- [ ] Can delete saved components

### Styling
- [ ] Follows existing glass/terminal styling

## Dependencies

- `react-resizable-panels` (already installed)
- Standard iframe (no external deps)
- localStorage for persistence (Supabase optional future)

## prepared.prompt

# Fix Kanban beads sync to use bd ready for Ready column

## Objective
Update the Kanban Ready column to accurately show only issues that are ready to work on, as determined by `bd ready --json` (issues with no blockers and prepared prompts), instead of using a heuristic based on description length.

## Dependency Note
**This issue depends on personal-homepage-cp7 (Add /api/beads/ready endpoint).** Wait for that endpoint to be merged before starting this task.

## Context
The kanban board has 5 columns: Backlog, Ready, In Progress, Blocked, and Done. Currently, the Ready column uses a faulty heuristic in `useBeadsBan.ts` that checks if `issue.description.trim().length > 0` to determine if an issue is "ready". This doesn't match beads actual logic.

**Current behavior (lines 222-230 in useBeadsBan.ts):**
```typescript
if (issue.description && issue.description.trim().length > 0) {
  return 'ready'
}
return 'backlog'
```

**Problem:** Issues with any description show as Ready, but they might have blockers or lack a prepared worker prompt.

## Specific Changes Required

### 1. Add fetchReady() function
Create a new API wrapper function (around line 117 in useBeadsBan.ts) that calls the new `/api/beads/ready` endpoint:

```typescript
async function fetchReady(workspace?: string): Promise<string[]> {
  try {
    const params = workspace ? `?workspace=${encodeURIComponent(workspace)}` : ''
    const res = await fetch(`/api/beads/ready${params}`)
    if (!res.ok) return []
    const data = await res.json()
    return data.ready?.map((issue: BeadsApiIssue) => issue.id) ?? []
  } catch {
    return []
  }
}
```

### 2. Update getColumnForIssue() logic (lines 206-230)
Replace the description-based heuristic with a Set lookup:

**Modify getColumnForIssue() to accept a readyIssueIds parameter:**

```typescript
function getColumnForIssue(
  issue: BeadsApiIssue,
  readyIssueIds: Set<string>
): BeadsBanColumnId {
  const status = issue.status?.toLowerCase()
  const hasBlockers = issue.blockedBy && issue.blockedBy.length > 0

  if (status === 'closed' || status === 'done') {
    return 'done'
  }
  if (status === 'blocked' || (status === 'open' && hasBlockers)) {
    return 'blocked'
  }
  if (status === 'in_progress' || status === 'in-progress') {
    return 'in-progress'
  }
  
  // Use bd ready to determine if issue is ready
  if (status === 'open' && readyIssueIds.has(issue.id)) {
    return 'ready'
  }
  return 'backlog'
}
```

### 3. Update refresh() callback (lines 286-353)
Fetch the ready issues list and pass it to getColumnForIssue():

- Call `fetchReady()` alongside `fetchIssues()` at the beginning of the refresh logic (around line 293)
- Convert the array to a Set for O(1) lookup: `const readySet = new Set(readyIds)`
- Pass `readySet` to all `getColumnForIssue(issue, readySet)` calls in the loop (line 309)

## Integration with /api/beads/ready

The new endpoint (personal-homepage-cp7) will:
- Accept GET request with optional `?workspace=PATH` query param
- Return `{ ready: BeadsApiIssue[] }` containing only issues that `bd ready --json` returns
- Issues in this list have:
  - `status: 'open'`
  - No blockers (blockedBy array is empty or undefined)
  - Prepared worker prompts (notes field contains prepared.prompt)

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `fetchReady()` function added and correctly calls `/api/beads/ready`
- [ ] `getColumnForIssue()` signature updated to accept `readyIssueIds: Set<string>`
- [ ] All calls to `getColumnForIssue()` pass the Set from `fetchReady()`
- [ ] Ready column now shows only issues returned by `bd ready --json`
- [ ] Backlog column shows open issues without blockers that aren't in the ready list
- [ ] TypeScript compiles without errors
- [ ] Manual test: Open kanban board, verify Ready column matches `bd ready --json` output
- [ ] No regression: Other columns (In Progress, Blocked, Done) unchanged

## Testing Strategy

1. **Unit logic:** Verify `getColumnForIssue()` correctly routes issues based on the readySet
2. **Integration:** Load kanban board and check Ready column matches `bd ready --json`
3. **Edge cases:**
   - Issue with blockers but prepared prompt: should be in Blocked, not Ready
   - Open issue with prepared prompt but no blockers: should be in Ready
   - Create a test issue, prepare it, verify it moves to Ready

## Notes

- The /api/beads/ready endpoint will be the source of truth for Ready column
- This maintains the 5-column structure (Backlog, Ready, In Progress, Blocked, Done)
- Error handling: if `/api/beads/ready` fails, readySet will be empty and all open issues go to Backlog (safe fallback)

title: Music: Add to queue gives JSON parse error
description:
## Bug: Add to Queue JSON Parse Error

### Error
```
Unexpected token 'X', "X7t2uqIsQr"... is not valid JSON
at JSON.parse
at spotifyFetch (lib/spotify.ts:477:15)
at async addToQueue (lib/spotify.ts:569:3)
```

### Root Cause
Different from the removeTracks bug! Spotify is returning a **non-empty, non-JSON response** (looks like a snapshot ID or token).

The current spotifyFetch fix handles empty responses but not text responses:
```typescript
const text = await response.text()
if (!text) return {} as T  // Only handles empty
return JSON.parse(text)    // Fails on non-JSON text like 'X7t2uqIsQr...'
```

### Fix Location
`lib/spotify.ts` line 475-477

### Solution
Add JSON content-type check:
```typescript
const text = await response.text()
if (!text) return {} as T

// Check if response is actually JSON
const contentType = response.headers.get('content-type')
if (!contentType?.includes('application/json')) {
  return {} as T  // Non-JSON response, return empty for void functions
}

return JSON.parse(text)
```

### Related
- Fixes both addToQueue AND any other endpoint returning non-JSON

title: Fix Analytics page showing incorrect token usage
description:
## Bug
Analytics page shows 376.4k total tokens for last 7 days, but Claude Code /stats shows much higher usage:

**Claude Code /stats (Last 7 days):**
- Opus 4.5 (94.2%): In: 1.7m, Out: 282.2k
- Haiku 4.5 (3.3%): In: 67.4k, Out: 441
- Sonnet 4.5 (2.5%): In: 51.7k, Out: 654

Total should be ~2.1M tokens, not 376.4k.

- analytics.tsx was generating random demo data instead of reading real stats
- Claude Code stores stats in ~/.claude/stats-cache.json
- The stats file contains dailyModelTokens (output tokens only per model per day) and modelUsage (totals with input/output/cache breakdown)

**Solution:**
- Created /api/claude-stats API route to read stats-cache.json
- Updated analytics.tsx to fetch from API on mount and refresh
- Used overall input/output ratio (1.1:1) for stable daily estimation instead of per-model ratios which caused inflation (Haiku has 136:1 ratio)

**What was tricky:**
- dailyModelTokens only contains OUTPUT tokens, not input
- Per-model input/output ratios vary wildly (Haiku 136:1, Opus 1.08:1)
- Had to use overall ratio across all models for stable estimation

**Testing notes:**
- Build passes
- Last 7 days now shows ~5.1M tokens (vs 376.4k demo data)
- Could not test live API since dev server runs on main worktree

title: Music Audit: Clear spotify-auth=pending from URL after successful auth
description:
## Bug: spotify-auth=pending Not Cleared from URL

### Root Cause Analysis
The OAuth callback flow sets a URL parameter that's never cleaned up:

**app/api/spotify/callback/route.ts line 197:**
```typescript
window.location.href = '/?section=music-player&spotify-auth=pending';
```

**hooks/useSpotifyAuth.ts** handles the auth but **never clears the URL parameter**:
- Line 132-161: `checkPendingAuth` effect reads from sessionStorage
- After successful auth, sessionStorage is cleared (line 140)
- But the URL still shows `?section=music-player&spotify-auth=pending`

### Why This Matters
1. **UX Issue:** Ugly URL after login
2. **Bookmarking:** Users might bookmark the pending URL
3. **Refresh Bug:** Refreshing the page with this URL triggers unnecessary auth checks

### Fix Location
`hooks/useSpotifyAuth.ts` around line 156 (after successful auth)

### Solution
Add URL cleanup after successful authentication:
```typescript
// After setting tokens and user successfully:
if (window.location.search.includes('spotify-auth=pending')) {
  const url = new URL(window.location.href)
  url.searchParams.delete('spotify-auth')
  window.history.replaceState({}, '', url.toString())
}
```

### Files to Modify
- `hooks/useSpotifyAuth.ts` - Add URL cleanup in checkPendingAuth effect

### Test Steps
1. Logout from Spotify
2. Login via OAuth redirect (not popup)
3. After successful auth, verify URL no longer contains spotify-auth=pending
4. Verify browser history doesn't show duplicate entries

When using Read Aloud on a file in the Files page, a popup shows garbled text with spaces removed. The text includes PRIME.md content, suggesting the MCP CLI call is picking up Claude context.

The /api/tabz/speak route uses `claude --mcp-cli call tabz/tabz_speak` which starts a Claude session and loads PRIME.md. The response somehow gets contaminated and has spaces stripped.
notes:
## Investigation

The Read Aloud feature in the Files page:
1. Fetches file content via `/api/files/content`
2. Sends to `/api/tabz/speak` which runs `claude --mcp-cli call tabz/tabz_speak`
3. The mcp-cli call loads Claude context including PRIME.md
4. Response shows garbled text with spaces stripped

## Possible fixes

1. **Call TabzChrome directly via HTTP** - if it exposes the speak endpoint
2. **Use a minimal Claude context** - pass `--system-prompt ""` or similar to skip PRIME.md
3. **Fix the mcp-cli response handling** - may have same newline stripping issue as chat streaming

## Files
- `app/api/tabz/speak/route.ts` - the TTS API route
- `app/components/files/FileTreeContextMenu.tsx:294-345` - handleReadAloud function
close_reason: Fixed: Now calls TabzChrome /api/audio/speak directly instead of going through claude --mcp-cli

title: Investigate TabzChrome new tab search bar for Search Hub enhancements
description:
The TabzChrome new tab page has a search bar that matches against multiple sources:
- Bookmarks
- Terminal profiles
- And more

This works really well and could inform enhancements to the Search Hub section or provide a unified quick-launch experience.

Reference: ~/projects/TabzChrome new tab page implementation
notes:
## Research Findings: TabzChrome New Tab Search Bar

### 1. How the CommandBar Works

The search bar is implemented in `extension/newtab/components/CommandBar.tsx`. Key features:

- **Single unified input** with `$` prefix aesthetic (terminal-style)
- **Live suggestions dropdown** appearing as user types
- **Auto-focus on mount** with 300ms delay for smooth UX
- **Debounced bookmark search** (150ms) to avoid excessive API calls

### 2. Search Sources

The CommandBar searches against **4 data sources**:

1. **URLs** - Detects URL patterns (http/https or domain-like strings like `github.com`)
2. **Terminal Profiles** - Matches profile name OR category via simple `includes()` string matching
3. **Recent Directories** - File paths matching the query
4. **Chrome Bookmarks** - Using `chrome.bookmarks.search()` API with 150ms debounce

Fallback: If no matches found and not a URL, suggests a Google search.

### 3. Matching Logic

**NOT fuzzy matching** - uses simple `toLowerCase().includes()` for profiles/dirs.

Matching priorities in suggestion generation order:
1. URL detection first (if looks like URL)
2. Profile matches (up to 4 results)
3. Directory matches (up to 3 results)
4. Bookmark matches (up to 5 results)
5. Fallback search suggestion

### 4. UI Patterns

**Keyboard Navigation:**
- `ArrowDown/Tab` - Next suggestion
- `ArrowUp/Shift+Tab` - Previous suggestion
- `Enter` - Execute selected action
- `Escape` - Close suggestions, clear input
- `/` key (from NewTab.tsx) - Focus search from anywhere on page
- `1-9` keys - Quick spawn profiles by index

**Visual Design:**
- Each suggestion has: icon, title, subtitle, action badge
- Color-coded icons by type (profile color or amber for bookmarks)
- Selected state with left border accent
- CRT-inspired aesthetic with scanlines/noise overlays

**Suggestion Item Structure:**
```typescript
interface Suggestion {
  type: 'profile' | 'url' | 'search' | 'dir' | 'bookmark'
  id: string
  title: string
  subtitle?: string
  icon?: React.ReactNode
  color?: string
  action: () => void
}
```

### 5. Additional Features

**Omnibox Integration** (`background/omnibox.ts`):
- `term <command>` from Chrome address bar
- Profile suggestions, URL handling, common commands
- Max 5 suggestions

**Web Shortcuts Grid:**
- Pulls from Chrome bookmarks "New Tab" or "Favorites" folder
- Google favicon API for icons
- Grid layout with hover effects

### 6. Enhancement Ideas for Search Hub

**High-Impact:**
1. **Unified quick-launch bar** - Single input that searches bookmarks + engines + AI services
2. **Keyboard shortcuts** - `1-9` for engine selection, `/` to focus
3. **Suggestion dropdown** - Show matching bookmarks/recent searches as user types
4. **Type-ahead with categories** - Group suggestions by source (bookmark, engine, recent)

**Medium-Impact:**
1. **Command palette style** - `Cmd+K` to open overlay search
2. **Shortcut prefixes** - `b:` for bookmarks, `g:` for google, etc.
3. **Debounced search** - Prevent excessive API calls while typing
4. **Mouse hover selection** - Update selected index on hover

**Lower-Priority:**
1. **Recent directories** integration (if terminal support exists)
2. **Chrome bookmarks API** (would need extension context)
3. **CRT visual effects** (might not fit homepage aesthetic)

### Key Files Reference

- `~/projects/TabzChrome/extension/newtab/components/CommandBar.tsx` - Main search component
- `~/projects/TabzChrome/extension/newtab/NewTab.tsx` - Parent with keyboard shortcuts
- `~/projects/TabzChrome/extension/newtab/styles/newtab.css` - Styling patterns
- `~/projects/TabzChrome/extension/background/omnibox.ts` - Address bar integration

title: Music Audit: Fix JSON parse error in spotify.ts removeTracks
description:
## Bug: JSON Parse Error in removeTracks

### Root Cause Analysis
The `removeTracks` function in `lib/spotify.ts:654-658` calls `spotifyFetch` with a DELETE request:

```typescript
export async function removeTracks(trackIds: string[]): Promise<void> {
  await spotifyFetch('/me/tracks', {
    method: 'DELETE',
    body: JSON.stringify({ ids: trackIds }),
  })
}
```

The issue is in `spotifyFetch` at line 474 which always calls `response.json()`:
- DELETE requests to `/me/tracks` return **204 No Content** on success
- Line 465-467 handles 204 correctly by returning `{} as T`
- **BUT** the Spotify API sometimes returns **200 OK with empty body** instead of 204

### Fix Location
`lib/spotify.ts` line ~470-474:
```typescript
// Current code tries to parse JSON even for empty responses
return response.json()
```

### Solution
Add empty body check before JSON parsing:
```typescript
const text = await response.text()
if (!text) return {} as T
return JSON.parse(text)
```

### Affected Components
- `components/PersistentMusicDrawer.tsx` line 114 - toggleLike function
- `components/SpotifyPlayer.tsx` line 378 - toggleLike function

### Test Steps
1. Start music playback
2. Click heart icon to unlike a track
3. Verify no console error about JSON parsing

```typescript
// Instead of execFile('claude', ['--mcp-cli', 'call', 'tabz/...'])
const res = await fetch('http://localhost:8129/api/bookmarks/search?q=...')
```

title: Music Audit: Consolidate duplicate device selectors
description:
## Bug: Duplicate Device Selectors Out of Sync

### Root Cause Analysis
There are **two independent device selectors** that don't share state:

1. **PersistentMusicDrawer.tsx** (lines 272-309)
   - Uses `player.devices` from `useMusicPlayerSafe()`
   - Calls `player.refreshDevices()` and `player.switchDevice()`
   - Device list: `player.devices`
   - Current device: `player.deviceId`

2. **SpotifyPlayer.tsx** (lines 201-239 - DeviceSelector component)
   - Receives `devices`, `currentDeviceId`, `onSelect`, `onRefresh` as props
   - Used at line ~470 with same `devices` array from `useSpotifyPlayer`

### Why They Desync
Both use the **same hook** (`useSpotifyPlayer`) but:
- `PersistentMusicDrawer` accesses via `MusicPlayerProvider` context
- `SpotifyPlayer` calls `useSpotifyPlayer` directly (separate instance!)
- When one refreshes, the other doesn't update

### Solution Options
**Option A (Recommended):** Remove device selector from SpotifyPlayer.tsx since PersistentMusicDrawer is always visible
**Option B:** Make SpotifyPlayer.tsx use the MusicPlayerProvider context instead of calling useSpotifyPlayer directly

### Files to Modify
- `components/SpotifyPlayer.tsx` - Remove DeviceSelector or use context
- Ensure single source of truth for device state

### Test Steps
1. Open music player section
2. Verify only one device selector visible
3. Switch devices and verify state is consistent
